titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr: Greenleaf called on me this morning, and I went with him down to the Bridge, where we found Mr: Bass at work upon the road— We cross’d the Bridge, and bespoke some necessary timber, at Mr: Pope’s in Dorchester— We viewed some of the newly constructed Salt-works, on a plan somewhat different from those I had seen before— Return’d to dinner— This afternoon I unpack’d a couple of the chests I had pack’d up in Holland to go to Lisbon, and which have remained eight years in that State— Found many of the books damaged— Went down to my fathers and spent an hour— Returned home early in the Evening.

2. Laying out my Garden— Dined and pass’d most of the day at my father’s— Dr: Putnam and Mr: Shaw came out from Boston this afternoon.— Tea and Evening at Mr: Millar’s— The Quincy neighbourhood chiefly there— Home early— My Reading this day has been, Juvenal Satire 3—Cicero pro Quintio—and Orrery’s Remarks on Swift. I received letters from Messrs: Willink of Amsterdam— Mr: & Mrs: W. Payne were here this afternoon.

3. Walking to my father’s this morning, I met Mr: Casaux, who was enquiring for my house— He brought a letter from Washington to Eliza— I took him first to my father’s, and after a visit there of half an hour came with him to my house— He return’d to Boston to dinner— Dr: and Mrs: Welsh were here this afternoon— As was my Aunt Smith. We spent the Evening at Mr: Apthorp’s— Generally the same Company as yesterday at Mr: Millar’s— Finished reading the 3d: and began the 4th: Satire of Juvenal.

4. My brother returned from Dedham last Evening, and was here this morning— Mrs: Adams and Eliza, with George dined at my father’s— I dined with the Club at Mr: Barrett’s— Pass’d an hour of the Evening at my father’s— Reading the 4th: Satire of Juvenal, and Orrery’s Remarks on Swift. Examining also the first Volume of the Journals of Congress with a view to trace the origin and progress of the debts and finances of the United States. I was not very well; and found myself in some degree incapable of application.

5. It rained all the morning which prevented me from attending meeting; in the afternoon I heard Mr: Porter of Roxbury. The sermon was on the importance of good example— I went to my fathers for a couple of Hours; and returned home early in the Evening.— Reading—finished Juvenal’s 4th: Satire— Consulted Gibbon’s Extraits Raisonnés, & read what he there says of Juvenal.

6. Mr: Greenleaf called on me this morning and I went down with him to Neponsit Bridge— Mr: Black followed us. We inspected the work of Mr: Bass in raising the road, and had some conversation with two Messrs: Billings respecting a fence, to be made with them— I return’d and dined at my father’s; where I found my Aunt Smith. Early in the Evening I came home— Read part of Juvenal’s 5th: Satire—Gibbon—Extraits Raisonnés, and some of Orrery’s letters on Swift— This afternoon my brother Thomas Boylston Adams was chosen Representative, for the town of Quincy, in the Legislature of this Commonwealth— Mr: Black declined re-election.

7. I went to Boston this morning, and brought Charlotte Welsh out to my father’s House— I dined at Dr: Welsh’s; but he was himself not at home— My time was principally occupied in making purchases of necessary Articles— Saw Mr: Dexter, respecting Mrs: S. Hall’s affairs— He has not yet formed his opinion— Call’d twice at Mr: J. Russell’s, respecting the business of R. Bird’s Assignees; but he was not in town— At Mr: Shaw’s Office— Saw there the Edinburgh Review of my Silesian Letters— Very much as I expected.

8. Day spent at home— Tea and Evening at Mr: D. Greenleaf’s, with a company of more than twenty ladies, and a smaller number of Gentlemen— Captain Beale was here this morning, and desires me to take further steps for him to recover the arrears due to him from the public on account of his son’s pay &c— I am now in such a situation that I can scarcely give any time to study— The petty avocations to which I am unavoidably condemned are innumerable and incessant— They are the death of all application— I am still on Juvenal’s 5th: Satire— Still reading the Life of Sir William Jones— And this day looked into Hurd’s Commentary on Horace.

9. Confined at home the principal part of the day— This afternoon I went to Captain Beale, with his papers for the Navy department prepared. Sent them by the Mail.— Pass’d a couple of hours at my father’s— Return’d home with Dexter— Read Juvenal—(finished the 5th: Satire.)— Life of Sir William Jones— And Orrery’s letters on Swift.

10. Mrs: Adams and Eliza Johnson went to Boston together— I dined at my father’s and took George there with me— We returned early this Evening, and found the Ladies had got home.— In my reading I began the 6th: Satire of Juvenal, and continued Cicero’s Oration for Roscius.— Much of the day spent in indolent repose.

11. Dined at my father’s, with the club in my brother’s turn— My wife and Eliza Johnson also dined there. We came home early this Evening— Had a severe thunder-storm which began in the afternoon, and continued almost all Night— Read Juvenal, Satire 6.— Gibbon’s Memoirs, diverse passages— And finished Orrery’s letters on Swift. They are written in a very elegant Style; and are amusing by the manner, intermingling anecdotes of the writer with criticisms on his works— Besides which they contain many miscellaneous remarks upon characters and topics incidentally mentioned, without any peculiar connection either with Swift or his writings.

12. Heard this morning a Mr: Buster of Pembroke, at Meeting, and this afternoon Mr: Blackburn at Church. Charlotte Welsh Mr: Shaw and my brother were with us at tea. After which we went to Mr: Millar’s, and thence in the Evening to my father’s— Mr: Shaw came home with us and then return’d— Reading Juvenal Satire 6. Tillotson’s Sermon 67. vol: 4. I am taking up again this writer with whom I began at least five years ago at Berlin, and in whose works I have yet advanced only thus far— Yet I always read him with pleasure.

13. Divided the forenoon between my farm and my books— Pruned a number of my young apple-trees— In the Evening I went to Mr: Cranch’s, and also to my father’s. Home somewhat late— Mrs: Black was here this morning; and also my brother— Reading, Juvenal Satire 6.— Martyn’s letters on Botany, and Sir William Jones’s life.

14. I was up this morning at 5. Walk’d to my father’s, and went with him to Cambridge; to attend the installation of Mr: Ware as professor of Divinity, and Mr: Peck as Professor of Natural History. My mother went into Boston. We called to visit Mrs: Dana, whom we found at home— At ten O’Clock we went into the philosophy chamber, and thence in procession to the Meeting-House— Mr: Ware was first inducted, and after taking the Oaths of Allegiance to the Commonwealth, and to support the Constitution of the United States, which were administered by the Lieutenant Governor, and making a declaration for the faithful performance of his duties, was by Professor Pearson announced as Professor of Divinity, and delivered a short discourse in elegant Latin relative to the functions of the Office— A similar ceremony was then performed with respect to Mr: Peck; though with some varieties in the forms— His discourse was in English— The professorship is a new foundation by a subscription of several private Gentlemen in Boston and elsewhere.— The services were finished just at 2 O’Clock. The Company returned in procession to the College, where those invited, dined in the Hall, with the Government of the College, and the Students. The subscribers to the fund for the other professorship dined together at Porter’s— The dinner in the Hall was very short, and about 4 P.M. after calling at Mr: Greenleaf’s we return’d to Boston— Took my mother at Mr: Smith’s. I found R. Norton at Shaw’s Office; and we all took tea at Mr: Otis’s— He came home with his daughter just as we were coming away— I also called on Mr: Jos: Russell, whom at length I found, but could not finish my business with him— When we got to my father’s at Quincy, just at dusk in the Evening, I found my wife and Eliza Johnson there— We walk’d home— I found myself very unwell, on going to bed.

15. Very ill all Night with a high fever— And entirely deprived of rest— Of course unwell all this day— Confined to the house altogether, as well; by the weather as by my indisposition— Eliza Johnson went down to my father’s— Reading still—Juvenal Satire 6. Some letters in the Appendix to Sir William Jones’s Memoirs— Dr: Hawkesworth’s Almoran and Hamet; and in the Evening Moore’s Anacreon— Writing— Review of Gifford’s Juvenal.

16. My father was here early this morning— I continued still unwell this day, though after a good Night’s rest.— Storm and rain the whole day, without intermission; so that I was again confined to the house— Reading— Juvenal Sat: 6. continued, Appendix to Sir W. Jones’s life— Almoran and Hamet— Evening; Moore’s Anacreon— Writing— Collections from the Journals of Congress— Debts U.S.—and Review of Gifford’s Juvenal.— My brother went yesterday Morning, for Haverhill; where he was this day to be married to Miss Nancy Harrod.

17. The Storm continued the greatest part of this day, but cleared up this afternoon— I went down to my father’s, and spent an hour there— I continue quite unwell— Reading, the same books as yesterday, in continuation— Writing the same.

18. Another Night entirely sleepless— My mother called here this morning— I finally went to Dr: Phipps for advice respecting my thumb. He gave me a salve or liniment, which relieved me before Night from pain. I spent the day at my father’s— Came home early in the Evening— Finished reading Juvenal’s 6th: Satire— But my indisposition has compelled me to abandon all other studies, and doomed me to idleness.

19. Heard Mr: Whitney this morning; but I was so much fatigued, and worn out with my state of health, that I staid at my father’s from Noon untill the Evening— I read this morning part of Juvenal’s 7th: Satire; and did nothing else the remainder of the day— Mrs: J. Greenleaf with her children was at my fathers at tea— Mrs: Adams and Eliza were at Mr: Cranch’s.

20. Had another restless and sleepless Night— At two in the morning I rose and dress’d; came below, and read a couple of hours— Belinda; a novel by Miss Edgeworth— I then return’d to bed, and continued to read two or three hours more there— Then Rose— Mr: Whitney called to see us— Mr: T. Greenleaf also call’d, and I rode down with him to Neponset Bridge, where Mr: Bass is finishing his work. I returned to my father’s to dinner— In the afternoon I went over to Weymouth with my mother, and consulted Dr: Tufts upon my complaints— He advised me to some medecine; much exercise, and a total relaxation from study— Mr: Cushman, and several Ladies were at Dr: Tufts’s— Came home soon after dusk, after returning home with my mother.

21. Somewhat better this day; but still feeble, and feverish— My father and mother call’d this afternoon; but did not stop. I am not able to write— Nor to read with any application— Finished examining the Seventh Satire of Juvenal— I found one or two passages which I had not before perfectly understood; though I have translated it myself. Read further in Miss Edgeworth’s Belinda.

22. Mr: T. Greenleaf and his lady were here this forenoon— My father came to invite us all to dinner, with Mr: & Mrs: J. Greenleaf— We accordingly went— Home early in the Evening— I was so much better that I began to think I might again do something; but in the Evening was threatened again with fever &c.— Read part of Juvenal’s 8th: Satire— Two of Pliny’s letters—and Belinda—Vol. 2.

23. I had another restless and sleepless Night— Of course this was a dull and tedious day. This Evening, went with my wife and Eliza Johnson, to see Mr: D. Greenleaf, and his wife, who is unwell— Reading— Juvenal 8th: Satire— A letter of Pliny— And with the ladies, two of Rousseau’s Botanical letters— Martyn’s translation— Belinda Vol: 2. & 3.

24. I have a slow, nervous and irregular fever, which comes and goes from day to day; but which chiefly takes me in the Night and deprives me of sleep. My Mother was here this Morning, and took George with her to spend the day— I went down for him this Evening; but he return’d with my mother— Read Juvenal’s 8th: Sat: and Belinda.

25. Sleepless and feverish Night again— My youngest child this day fell into a tub of rain-water, and was almost drown’d when Eliza Johnson took him out of it— He had a violent fever all the remainder of the day— His Maid had carelessly left him— George ran in and told us he had dropt his hat in the water. In two minutes more he must have perished— We call’d in Dr: Phipps who came several times in the course of the day— Mr: Father was here towards Evening; having then first heard of the accident— My Mother was gone to Boston— The child grew better towards Night— Reading— Finished Juvenal Sat: 8. read a couple of Rousseau’s botanical letters— Belinda Vol: 3.

26. The child appeared to be so well this Morning, that our anxiety for him was quite removed; and I took George with me to Meeting, where I heard Mr: Whitney— Dined at My father’s— After Meeting in the afternoon I came home, and found Dr: Phipps with John who was again excessively ill; with a violent fever, and extreme oppression upon the lungs— He had continued apparently well untill about 2 O’Clock, when the fever and illness came on him very suddenly— He continued very ill with many alarming symptoms, all the Evening; but seemed late at Night a little easier— Captain Kirkland, and his younger brother, called to see us this afternoon. My father and Mother were here at tea— I had last Night another sleepless and restless Night, and have been quite unwell this whole day— Reading— Juvenal Satire 9. and two Sermons of Tillotson—68 & 69— Good Men Strangers & Sojourners on Earth.

27. My child continues to have a severe fever, but appears to be much better than yesterday— After passing the morning at home, I went and dined at my father’s— Return’d home early this afternoon, my Mother came with
me, and stay’d untill the Evening— My own health is a little better than for sometime past— Read Belinda, and finished Juvenal Satire 9.

28. I went into Boston this morning with my father, and attended the annual meeting of the Academy, for the choice of Officers— Subscribed for myself and my brother to the fund for the Professorship of Natural History, at Cambridge, and paid for both the Subscriptions; as also for my father’s— He furnished the money for the whole. The Officers of the Academy were re-elected— And Judge Dana was elected Vice-President in the room of the late President Willard— I dined with Judge Davis— His brother, from Plymouth, Coll: Partridge, and Mr: Gannett were there— My father dined at Whitcomb’s— We return’d to Quincy early in the Evening— I found my child a little better— My brother arrived this Evening with his wife, but I did not see him—

29. Annual Election Day— I went down to my father’s this morning, to do some business for my brother— Saw his wife; whom I had not before seen these fifteen years or more— Return’d home to dinner— I was again quite unwell all this afternoon— I find it yet impossible to reverse the doom of idleness and mental imbecility to which I have been condemned.— Finished Belinda, but could read nothing else— I took up a volume of the additions to Pope, but found myself altogether unable to read with any profit— I therefore laid it down again, and sunk into the state of vegetation— Mrs: Smith pass’d the afternoon here.

30. My child appears happily to be recovering; and I may now indulge the hope that he has escaped from the danger of that dreadful accident— We took him out to ride this Morning; and afterwards went all and dined at my father’s— My wife return’d immediately after dinner— And I came home early in the Evening.— But I was unwell, the greatest part of the day— Reading— Began Juvenal’s 10th: Satire— On the Vanity of Human wishes.

31. My Mother, and my brother’s wife were here this forenoon— I spent the day at home— My health appears to be improving; but I am still incapable of application— Reading— Juvenal’s 10. Satire— Cumberland’s fashionable Lover— Gay’s three hours after Marriage— A disgusting and dull thing.— A Letter of Rousseau on Botany.

Day. Rise usually between 5 and 6. Read Juvenal untill 9. Breakfast— Read, ramble about the fields, or go to my fathers to pass the forenoon; untill 2. dine— Pass the afternoon and Evening in total idleness. Bed at about 10.— Here is another instance of disappointed expectation— When I came to this house, with a prospect of long and uninterrupted leisure before me, my purpose was to apply it in a manner which should be useful to myself and others— It has pleased Heaven to reduce me to a state of health, in which my weakness both of body and Mind forbids every thing like study— Thus my prospects are again blasted, and I have nothing left before me but Resignation.
